choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Of the given statements regarding trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica is seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Fasciola hepatica is the largest and most common liver fluke found in man

 

Habitat - The parasite resides in the liver and biliary passages of the definitive host.

 

Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle and man.

 

Intermediate host: Snails

 

Mode of infection: The definitive host, sheep and man, get infection by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

 

Life cycle-

 

 

Unlike other trematodes and basically all other flatworms, the schistosomes are dioecious, i.e., the sexes are separate

 

Schistosoma – Cercariae penetrates through skin, eggs with terminal spine, only snails as intermediate hosts and separate sexes.

 

Praziquantel remains the drug of choice for all trematode infections except fascioliasis, for which triclabendazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma are monoecious: This statement is false. Schistosomes are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes (male and female), which is an exception among trematodes, as most are hermaphroditic.

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water: This statement is false. Fasciola hepatica infection is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation, not directly through contaminated water.

 

Option D. Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections: This statement is false. While triclabendazole is the drug of choice for fascioliasis, praziquantel remains the drug of choice for most other trematode infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Candida is a genus of yeast and is the most common cause of fungal infections in humans. It is characterized by its oval shape and its mode of reproduction through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. In a healthcare setting, particularly in the ICU, Candida infections are commonly associated with the use of central venous catheters. The yeast can colonize and infect these catheters, leading to systemic infections. The identification of a gram-positive, oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding points directly to Candida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium and does not reproduce by budding. It is typically associated with gastrointestinal infections, urinary tract infections, and other bacterial infections, but not with the description provided in this scenario.

 

Option C. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus in clusters and does not reproduce by budding. It is a common cause of various infections, including skin infections and catheter-associated infections, but its morphology and reproduction do not match the description of a budding organism.

 

Option D. Staph epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is also a gram-positive cocci and part of the normal skin flora. It is a common contaminant in blood cultures and can cause infections associated with indwelling medical devices, but it does not reproduce by budding and does not have an oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the standard agar recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using sensitivity discs? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Mueller Hinton Agar

 

Explanation:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the standard medium recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using the disc diffusion method. It provides consistent results due to its well-defined composition and is specifically designed for this purpose. For fastidious organisms, Mueller Hinton Blood Agar may be used as a modification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PLET Agar - This is not a standard medium for antibiotic susceptibility testing. PLET agar is a selective medium used for isolating specific bacteria Like Bacillus anthracis , not for determining their antibiotic sensitivity patterns.

 

Option B. Castañeda Agar - This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of Brucella species or fungus from blood cultures in a biphasic format (solid and liquid phases in the same container). It is not designed or standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing.

 

Option D. Cetrimide Agar - This is a selective medium used for the isolation and identification of Pseudomonas species, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Its composition is not standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing, and the cetrimide component would interfere with accurate antimicrobial testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the internationally accepted standard medium for antimicrobial susceptibility testing by the disc diffusion method due to its reproducibility, low content of inhibitors, and support of growth for most non-fastidious pathogens of clinical significance.

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dog

 

The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canis which are its definitive hosts.

 

The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.

 

Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

 

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

 

Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cat: Incorrect, as cats are not typical definitive hosts for Echinococcus species.

 

Option C. Swine: Incorrect, swine serve as one of the intermediate hosts, not as definitive hosts where the adult tapeworms reside.

 

Option D. Sheep: Incorrect, similar to swine, sheep act as intermediate hosts where larval stages develop, not as definitive hosts for the adult form of the tapeworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dogs are the definitive hosts for the adult form of Echinococcus, underscoring the importance of proper hygiene and preventive measures in areas where these animals are common to minimize the risk of transmission and subsequent human infection.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

questions.text: A truck driver is presenting with a painless ulcer with firm base, what is the next investigation you will prefer to do?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscopy for spirochetes

 

The presentation of a painless ulcer with a firm base is highly suggestive of a syphilitic chancre, which is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The most appropriate next investigation for diagnosing syphilis in this context is dark field microscopy.

 

 

Dark Field Microscopy:

 

  • It is used to directly visualize Treponema pallidum in fluid from the ulcer.
  • This method allows the detection of the characteristic motility of spirochetes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gram staining: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum is not effectively visualized with Gram staining due to its thin and delicate structure.

 

Option C. Tzanck smear for giant cells: Incorrect. Tzanck smear is used for diagnosing viral infections like herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which present with different clinical features such as painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Cell line culture: Incorrect. Cell culture is not routinely used for diagnosing syphilis and is more applicable for viral pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG2

 

IgG2 deficiency is the most likely culprit in cases where a child suffers from recurrent sinopulmonary infections specifically caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a critical role in the immune system's ability to fight off encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis. These organisms are particularly adept at evading non-specific immune responses due to their polysaccharide capsules, making specific antibody-mediated immunity crucial.

 

Transplacental Transport of IgG: IgG is unique among the immunoglobulins as it is transported from mother to fetus across the placenta, providing passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is transported most efficiently across the placenta, providing early defense against infection in neonates. IgG2, despite being critical for defense against encapsulated bacteria, has less transplacental movement, which can influence the susceptibility to infections in early infancy before the infant's own immune system fully matures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG1: Predominantly responsible for protecting against bacterial infections, including pathogens like diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. IgG3: Often associated with a stronger response to viral infections.

 

Option D. IgG4: Less common and typically related to responses against parasitic infections, though IgG4-related disease can also manifest as fibroinflammatory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children presenting with recurrent infections caused by encapsulated bacteria, IgG2 deficiency should be considered as a possible underlying cause. Early identification and management of specific immunoglobulin deficiencies are crucial to prevent recurrent infections and their complications in young children.

questions.text: Among the following, which bacterium is described as pleomorphic, Gram-positive small coccobacilli that exhibit tumbling motility? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Listeria monocytogenes).

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive, non-spore forming coccobacillus that exhibits a distinctive tumbling motility. This characteristic tumbling motility is temperature-dependent - present at 25°C but absent at 37°C. This differential motility pattern is a key identifying feature used in laboratory diagnosis and helps distinguish Listeria from other similar bacteria. The organism is also known for its ability to grow at refrigeration temperatures, making it a significant concern in food safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corynebacterium species - While Corynebacterium is a Gram-positive bacillus that appears pleomorphic with characteristic arrangements described as "Chinese letter" or "palisade" formations, it is non-motile. Corynebacterium species typically have metachromatic granules that stain with special dyes, but they lack the tumbling motility characteristic of Listeria.

 

Option C. Enterococcus species - Enterococcus is a Gram-positive coccus that typically appears in pairs or short chains, not as coccobacilli. Most of the species are non-motile except Enterococcus gallinarum and Enterococcus pullorum and are frequently described as having a "spectacle-shaped" appearance when arranged in pairs. They are facultative anaerobes known for their hardiness and antibiotic resistance.

 

Option D. Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae - This is a Gram-positive bacillus that can sometimes appear as short filaments. While it can cause infections in humans, particularly erysipeloid (a localized skin infection), it does not exhibit the tumbling motility characteristic of Listeria. It is primarily associated with infections acquired through occupational exposure to infected animals.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Listeria monocytogenes is uniquely characterized by its temperature-dependent tumbling motility, which serves as a critical diagnostic feature when identifying this foodborne pathogen that causes severe infections, particularly in pregnant women, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A child is presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash and spots in the oral cavity as shown in the given image, what is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

The clinical presentation of fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash, and characteristic spots in the oral cavity is indicative of measles. The spots shown in the image are Koplik spots, which are pathognomonic for measles.

 

Key Points about Measles:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by an RNA paramyxovirus.
  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Koplik Spots: Small, white lesions with a red base typically found opposite the lower second molar.
    • Rash: Starts behind the ears (retroauricular) and spreads downwards.
    • Other Symptoms: Fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cough.

 

Common Complications:

 

  • Most Common: Serous otitis media.
  • Serious Complication: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a late and fatal complication.
  • Histopathology: Presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox: Incorrect. Chicken pox (varicella) presents with a vesicular rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs and face. Oral lesions are not specific to chicken pox.

 

Option C. Mumps: Incorrect. Mumps typically presents with parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) and may have associated fever and orchitis in males. Koplik spots are not a feature of mumps.

 

Option D. Rubella: Incorrect. Rubella presents with a fine, pink rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs, but it does not present with Koplik spots. It is usually milder than measles and may have postauricular lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Koplik spots, along with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and rash, is highly indicative of measles.

questions.text: An adult female came with curdy white vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination showed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The key points indicate Candida albicans as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of candidiasis (yeast infection).
  2. Microscopic examination revealed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which are characteristic of Candida albicans.
  3. Pseudohyphae are elongated structures with constrictions at the septal junctions, distinguishing them from true hyphae found in molds.
  4. Among the options provided, Candida albicans is the only fungus that forms pseudohyphae.

 

Candida albicans is a yeast that can cause various fungal infections, including vaginal candidiasis (commonly known as a "yeast infection"). The formation of pseudohyphae, along with budding yeast cells, is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans observed under the microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is caused by an overgrowth of various bacteria, not a fungus like Candida albicans.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, not a fungus.

 

Option D.  Gonorrhoea: Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, presents with purulent discharge but does not produce yeast or pseudohyphae. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with gram stain and culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida albicans is a fungus that can cause vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), characterized by a curdy white vaginal discharge. The presence of gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans infections.

questions.text: Identify the organism seen in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

﻿﻿Image shows banana shaped gametocyte which is a feature of plasmodium falciparum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. vivax: Enlarged erythrocyte, Schaffner’s dots, and 'Ameboid' trophozoite are characteristic of P. vivax but it does not have banana-shaped gametocytes.

 

Option C. P. Knowlesi: P. knowlesi exhibits features similar to P. malariae but is not commonly recognized by banana-shaped gametocytes.

 

Option D. P. malariae: P. malariae shows compact parasites and merozoites in a rosette formation but lacks the characteristic banana-shaped gametocytes of P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of passive immunity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity occurs when antibodies are transferred to an individual without stimulating their immune system. The key characteristic of passive immunity is that it provides immediate but temporary protection, as it doesn't involve the host's immune system actively producing antibodies. Passive immunity can be acquired naturally (through maternal transfer) or artificially (through immunoglobulin administration).

 

A toxoid, being a modified form of bacterial toxin, actually stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies, making it a form of active immunity rather than passive immunity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Antitoxin: Incorrect because antitoxins are preformed antibodies against specific toxins. When administered, they provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, making them a true example of passive immunity.

 

Option C. IgA: Incorrect because maternal IgA transferred through breast milk is a classic example of naturally acquired passive immunity, providing immediate protection to infants.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibodies: Incorrect because these are laboratory-produced antibodies that provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, representing artificial passive immunity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Passive immunity involves direct antibody transfer without immune system stimulation, while active immunity (like toxoids) involves stimulating the immune system to produce its own antibodies.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

questions.text: Identify the parasite? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia. This protozoan parasite is known for its characteristic pear shape, with flagella and a "smiling face" appearance due to its two nuclei.

 

Giardia lamblia:

 

  • Morphology: Pear-shaped trophozoites with two nuclei that look like eyes and multiple flagella.
  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route, often through contaminated water or food.
  • Clinical Presentation: Causes giardiasis, which can present with symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss. Chronic infection may lead to malabsorption and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Diagnosis: Identification of trophozoites or cysts in stool samples, often using direct microscopy or immunoassays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis: This parasite causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. The trophozoites have a characteristic pear shape with a single nucleus and multiple flagella but lack the "smiling face" appearance.

 

 

 

Option C. Trypanosoma: This genus includes species such as Trypanosoma brucei and Trypanosoma cruzi, which cause African sleeping sickness and Chagas disease, respectively. These parasites are characterized by their elongated shape with a single flagellum.

 

 

 

Option D. Cyclospora: This protozoan parasite causes cyclosporiasis, presenting with watery diarrhea, and is typically identified by its oocysts in stool samples, which are not similar in appearance to Giardia lamblia.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia is identified by its distinct trophozoite form with a pear shape and two nuclei giving a "smiling face" appearance. It causes giardiasis, which is commonly diagnosed by detecting trophozoites or cysts in stool samples

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a heterophile agglutination test? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rose Waaler Test

 

Explanation:


The Rose Waaler Test is not a heterophile agglutination test but rather an autoantibody test used to detect rheumatoid factor. It involves sheep erythrocytes coated with a subagglutinating dose of anti-erythrocyte antibody that are used as antigen in an agglutination test. This test detects autoantibodies (Rheumatoid Factor) that react with the Fc fragment of IgG, making it fundamentally different from heterophile tests that involve cross-reactive antigens between different species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paul-Bunnell Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test. It's used in infectious mononucleosis to detect heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep or horse red blood cells. These antibodies develop in response to EBV infection but cross-react with antigens on these animal erythrocytes.

 

Option B. Weil-Felix Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test. It detects antibodies in rickettsial infections that cross-react with antigens of Proteus vulgaris bacteria, demonstrating shared epitopes between the different species.

 

Option D. Cold Agglutination Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test used in primary atypical pneumonia (Mycoplasma pneumoniae). It detects antibodies that cause agglutination of human erythrocytes at low temperatures through cross-reactive mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Heterophile agglutination tests involve antibodies produced against one organism that cross-react with antigens of unrelated organisms due to shared epitopes, while the Rose Waaler test detects autoantibodies specific to self-immunoglobulins.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: A microbiologist stained a tissue sample and found thin, filamentous bacteria, which resembled Nocardia sp. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the presence of Nocardia? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified acid-fast stain

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid (fast=holding capacity). Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ziehl-Neelsen staining is not specific for Nocardia as it is primarily used for Mycobacteria which require heating of the stain.

 

Option B: Silver impregnation is used for fungi and certain bacteria like Legionella, but not typically for Nocardia.

 

Option C: Albert stain is used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacteria, not for Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified acid-fast stain should be used to confirm the presence of Nocardia due to its weak acid-fast nature and characteristic "beaded" appearance.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

 

  • ﻿﻿Cutaneous Anthrax (hide porter's disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • ﻿﻿Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) - Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in wounds and burns, often producing a greenish pus but not typically associated with black eschars.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, associated with swollen and painful lymph nodes (buboes) rather than black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can present with ulcers at the infection site but lacks the characteristic black eschar of anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by the initial appearance of a small pimple that quickly turns into a painless ulcer with a necrotic (black) eschar at the center. This presentation is typical for individuals who have been in contact with infected animals or animal products, which is common in the veterinary profession.

 

Additional Information

 

Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is Known as the Father of Bacteriology.

 

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors
Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X

questions.text: What is the most suitable culture medium for Gram-negative coccobacilli isolated from a tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcer? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitale X

 

Explanation:

 

Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X is the most suitable medium for culturing Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of chancroid. This Gram-negative coccobacillus presents with the clinical picture of tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcers. H. ducreyi shows a characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" appearance on microscopy and requires special media for growth. Chocolate agar with isovitalex X  (provides essential nutrients for growth)  is specifically mentioned as one of the appropriate culture media for this fastidious organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thayer-Martin Medium - This medium is primarily used for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis from specimens that may contain mixed flora. While it's used for some Gram-negative diplococci, it's not the optimal medium for H. ducreyi which causes genital ulcers with the described characteristics.

 

Option B. Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors - While H. ducreyi does require X factor (hemin) for growth, simple blood agar with X and V factors is not sufficient. H. ducreyi is extremely fastidious and requires more specialized media such as chocolate agar with isovitalex X for optimal recovery. H. Influenza requires Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors for its growth. 

 

Option D. Tellurite blood agar - This medium is used primarily for isolating Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a Gram-positive bacillus. Tellurite is inhibitory to many organisms but allows C. diphtheriae to grow with characteristic black colonies. This medium is not suitable for the isolation of H. ducreyi from genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Haemophilus ducreyi, the cause of chancroid characterized by tender, non-indurated genital ulcers, is a highly fastidious Gram-negative coccobacillus that requires specialized media such as chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X for successful laboratory culture and diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory test result of leptospira IM reactivity, now presented with breathlessness, fever, and jaundice that worsened after treatment with penicillin. What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

 

The possible diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction typically occurs within 24 hours of starting antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, including syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • The breakdown of the spirochetes after antibiotic administration releases endotoxins and cytokines into the bloodstream.
  • This causes an acute inflammatory reaction, characterized by the release of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-8 (IL-8), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha).

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Symptoms include fever, chills, rigors, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and exacerbation of skin lesions.
  • The symptoms usually begin within 2 hours of antibiotic administration and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistant leptospirosis: This would present with ongoing symptoms despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, but not typically with acute worsening immediately after starting treatment.

 

Option B. Penicillin allergy: This would typically present with urticaria, pruritus, rash, or anaphylaxis, not with the acute inflammatory symptoms described.

 

Option C. Co-infection with dengue: This would be considered if there were signs and symptoms consistent with dengue, such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and hemorrhagic manifestations, but it does not explain the acute worsening after penicillin treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an acute inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of initiating antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, characterized by fever, chills, myalgia, and exacerbation of symptoms due to the release of inflammatory cytokines.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: Which of the following can grow in an acidic pH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactobacilli

 

Among the given options, lactobacilli is the one that can grow in an acidic pH.

 

It is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming bacterium. Lactobacillus derives lactic acid from glucose, creating an acidic environment and thus can grow in an acidic medium. It is found in the vagina as part of its normal microbiota.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Incorrect, as Vibrio species typically prefer alkaline conditions, such as those found in seawater.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella bacteria prefer a neutral to slightly acidic environment but do not thrive in highly acidic conditions.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella, like Salmonella, is more adapted to neutral or slightly acidic environments and does not generally grow well in highly acidic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactobacilli's ability to grow in acidic environments is crucial for their role in maintaining healthy microbial flora in certain parts of the human body, such as the vagina, and is also exploited in the fermentation of various food products.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The blotting techniques are named after their geographical directions and are used to detect specific biomolecules:

 

1-d. Southern blotting (developed by E.M. Southern) is used for DNA detection through DNA-DNA hybridization using radioactive or chromogenic DNA probes.

 

2-c. Northern blotting is used for RNA identification and follows similar principles as Southern blotting but targets RNA molecules.

 

3-a. Western blotting is used for protein identification through electrophoretic separation followed by antibody detection.

 

4-b. Eastern blotting is used for enzyme detection and post-translational modifications of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blotting techniques are specific: Southern for DNA, Northern for RNA, Western for proteins, and Eastern for enzymes. 

 

Mnemonic: Remember this from geographical directions: North-RNA (roti), South-DNA (dosa), West-Proteins (pizza), East-Enzymes (to digest proteins).

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV 2

 

In this scenario, the 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. The Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells, which are indicative of a herpes virus infection. Given the mother’s history of genital lesions, it is highly suggestive that the baby contracted the infection during delivery.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Vesicles: The presence of vesicles (fluid-filled blisters) is characteristic of herpes infections.
  • Tzanck Smear: This test shows multinucleate giant cells, which are typical findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.
  • Mother's Genital Lesions: This detail strongly indicates genital herpes, which is most commonly caused by HSV-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella Zoster: Although varicella zoster virus (VZV) can cause vesicles and multinucleate giant cells, the history of maternal genital lesions and the clinical presentation points more specifically towards HSV.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: This bacterium is not associated with vesicular lesions or multinucleate giant cells on Tzanck smear. It typically causes urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and endocarditis, not the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis can cause congenital infections but does not present with vesicular skin lesions or multinucleate giant cells. The typical findings include intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.

questions.text: Most common cause of diarrhoea in children: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

Rotavirus is consistently recognized as the most common cause of severe diarrheal disease in children worldwide. It is particularly significant in infants and young children, causing acute gastroenteritis. The virus primarily affects the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to malabsorption and secretory diarrhea. Rotavirus infection is characterized by:

 

  • Severe watery diarrhea
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Rapid dehydration, especially in young children

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Incorrect because while E. coli (particularly ETEC and EHEC strains) is an important cause of diarrhea in children, it is not the most common causative agent. E. coli typically causes traveler's diarrhea and some specific syndromes like hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

Option C. Ascaris: Incorrect because although Ascaris lumbricoides can cause various gastrointestinal symptoms, it is primarily a helminthic infection that doesn't typically present with diarrhea as the main symptom. Most Ascaris infections are actually asymptomatic.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect because while Shigella is an important cause of dysentery in children, it typically causes bloody diarrhea with mucus and is not the most common overall cause of childhood diarrhea. It is more associated with poor sanitation and hygiene conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe diarrheal disease in infants and young children worldwide.

 

Agents causing Traveler's diarrhea

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not common to both B cells and T cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Class I MHC Expression


Explanation:


T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Selection During Development: Both undergo positive selection in the thymus for T cells and bone marrow for B cells to ensure they can recognize self-MHC molecules

 

Option C. Antigen-Specific Receptors - This IS common to both. T cells possess T cell receptors (TCR) while B cells have surface immunoglobulins, both serving as antigen recognition units.

 

Option D. All of the above - This is incorrect because options B and C represent features shared by both cell types.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae binds with which receptors in the intestine? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, a disease characterized by severe watery diarrhea, often referred to as "rice water stools." The pathogenesis of cholera involves the cholera toxin, which plays a critical role in the disease process.

 

Upon ingestion of contaminated food or water, Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin in the intestinal lumen. The cholera toxin (2 subunits – A & B) does not enter the intestinal cells directly; instead, it binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of the intestinal epithelial cells. This binding facilitates the entry of the toxin into the cells.

 

Once inside the cell, the cholera toxin activates the enzyme adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP levels cause the inhibition of sodium absorption and an increase in chloride and water secretion into the intestinal lumen. This results in the characteristic watery diarrhea of cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. GM3: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option D. GM4: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP and resulting in watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Explanation:

 

The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.

 

While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.

 

Pernicious malaria -  (due to heavy parasitization)

 

  • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs

 

Other Options:

 

A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JC Virus: Known for causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in patients with severe immunodeficiency, but it is less common than CMV in affecting renal transplant patients in the early months post-transplant.

 

Option C. BK Virus: This virus can affect renal transplant recipients by causing BK virus-associated nephropathy, which can lead to graft dysfunction and loss. However, its peak incidence typically occurs slightly later than CMV.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): While EBV can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not as commonly the predominant pathogen in the early post-transplant period compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and managing CMV infection in the early months following renal transplantation is crucial due to its potential to cause significant morbidity and impact on graft survival. Monitoring for CMV activity and initiating pre-emptive or therapeutic antiviral treatment as indicated is key to improving transplant outcomes.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira

 

The life cycle shown in the images is indicative of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. The diagram highlights the transmission cycle involving various animal reservoirs and the environment, which is characteristic of leptospirosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanta virus: Transmitted through aerosolized rodent excreta but does not fit the detailed transmission cycle depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Causes plague, transmitted primarily through fleas, and does not follow the environmental cycle shown in the image.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food and water, and does not have a life cycle involving animal reservoirs as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Leptospira involves transmission from animal reservoirs through contaminated water and soil, leading to human infection, which fits the depiction in the provided images.

choices.text: Aplastic anemia - Patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia

questions.text: The following are parvovirus-related disease-population pairs. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE

 

Non-erosive arthritis is indeed a feature of parvovirus B19 infection, but it is not specifically associated with patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Instead, it can occur in otherwise healthy adults, often presenting as transient joint pain and swelling.

 

Other Options:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can cause several clinical syndromes depending on the patient's age and immune status:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia is typically seen in patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia, such as sickle cell disease, who develop transient aplastic crises due to parvovirus B19 infection. The virus targets erythroid progenitor cells, leading to a temporary cessation of red blood cell production.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis occurs in pregnant women when the fetus is infected with parvovirus B19. The infection can cause severe fetal anemia, leading to heart failure and generalized edema in the fetus.

 

Option C. Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or "slapped cheek" syndrome, commonly occurs in young children. It presents with a characteristic facial rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a visibly swollen neck. The child's parents mention that the symptoms started with a sore throat a few days ago. On physical examination, the child has a thick grayish-white membrane covering the tonsils and posterior pharynx, extending into the nasopharynx. The neck is noticeably swollen, giving it a "bull neck" appearance. Based on these findings, which causative organism is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Presented case with a child exhibiting symptoms of high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a swollen neck with the presence of a grayish-white membrane is highly suggestive of bull neck diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

  • Colony Appearance: Small, greyish-white, granular colonies with a matte or rough texture.
  • Gram Stain: Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria with irregular arrangements.
  • Culture Requirements: Special media like Loeffler's medium or Tinsdale agar are needed for growth.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corynebacterium ulcerans: Can cause diphtheria-like illness but is less common and typically associated with zoonotic transmission.

 

Option C. Corynebacterium minutissimum: Causes erythrasma, a superficial skin infection, and does not produce a pseudomembrane or systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium tenuis: Associated with trichomycosis axillaris, a superficial infection of hair shafts, and does not cause diphtheria-like illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the causative organism of diphtheria, characterized by the formation of a grayish-white pseudomembrane in the throat, high fever, and a swollen neck (bull neck). Early recognition and treatment are critical to managing this potentially life-threatening infection.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oocysts

 

Oocysts are the infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii that are shed in the feces of infected cats. These oocysts are highly resistant and can survive in the environment for extended periods, becoming infectious to other hosts, including humans, once they sporulate. When a pregnant woman comes into contact with these oocysts, there is a risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, which can lead to serious congenital abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradyzoites are the form of Toxoplasma that are found within tissue cysts in intermediate hosts.

 

Option B. Tissue cysts, containing bradyzoites, are found in intermediate hosts such as rodents and birds, and not in cat feces.

 

Option C. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite that disseminates throughout the host's tissues during acute infection but are not the form found in cat feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements from the following options: (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Widal test done in first week of illness
  2. Microscopic agglutination test in Leptospira
  3. Weil Felix test in typhus fever
  4. Standard agglutination test in Brucellosis
  5. VDRL used for Treponema pallidum
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b, c, d, e

 

b. True - Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is indeed used for Leptospira diagnosis. This is the gold standard serological test for leptospirosis.

 

c. True - Weil-Felix test is used for typhus fever diagnosis. It's a heterophile agglutination test that detects rickettsial antibodies using Proteus antigens (OX19, OX2, OXK strains).

 

d. True - Standard agglutination test (SAT) is used for Brucellosis diagnosis. This is also known as slide agglutination test for Brucella species.

 

e. True - VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is used as a screening test for Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. It's a non-treponemal test.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

a. False - Widal test is done in the second week of illness, not the first week. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serological tests have specific organisms and timing: MAT for Leptospira, Weil-Felix for typhus, SAT for Brucella, VDRL for syphilis screening, and Widal test is performed in the second week of typhoid fever.

 

Mnemonic: “BASU” - Blood culture (1st week), Agglutination/Widal (2nd week), Stool culture (3rd week), Urine culture (4th week).

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan region presents with multiple ulcers on the leg. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Sporothrix schenckii

 

Explanation:

 

The case describes a patient from the sub-Himalayan region with multiple ulcers on the leg. This clinical presentation strongly suggests sporotrichosis, which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Sporotrichosis is frequently encountered in gardeners, forest workers and manual laborers, with the sub-Himalayan hilly areas being an endemic region in India. The disease typically manifests as noduloulcerative lesions that develop following traumatic implantation, such as from a thorn prick, which is common in agricultural workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton rubrum: Incorrect because T. rubrum is a dermatophyte that causes superficial mycoses like tinea (ringworm) infections. It typically presents with circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy lesions rather than ulcers. Dermatophytoses don't typically progress to form multiple ulcers as described in this case.

 

Option B. Cudotrichum species: This genus is not a known human pathogen causing subcutaneous or cutaneous infections with the presentation described.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species predominantly cause respiratory infections (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis) or superficial infections like otomycosis. They don't typically cause multiple cutaneous ulcers in immunocompetent individuals, especially not in the pattern described for this farmer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Sporotrichosis is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii that frequently affects agricultural workers and presents as noduloulcerative lesions along lymphatics (lymphocutaneous form) following minor trauma, with the sub-Himalayan region being an endemic area for this infection in India.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg + IgM anti-HBc

 

Explanation:
