Acute Hepatitis B is diagnosed based on specific serological markers. The presence of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen (IgM anti-HBc) indicates an acute infection. Here’s a detailed explanation:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen is present on the surface of the Hepatitis B virus and indicates an active infection. It is one of the first markers to appear in the blood following infection.
  2. IgM anti-HBc (IgM antibodies to Hepatitis B core antigen): The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection, as IgM is produced early in the immune response. This marker is crucial in differentiating acute from chronic infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgG anti-HBc: The presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates a past or chronic infection. It is not specific for acute infection.

 

Option C. anti-HBs: The presence of anti-HBs antibodies indicates recovery and immunity from Hepatitis B infection, either due to past infection or vaccination.

 

Option D. HBeAg: This antigen indicates active viral replication and high infectivity but does not differentiate between acute and chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Hepatitis B is characterized by the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc, which indicate an active and recent infection.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is strongly associated with "Mucormycosis"? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic ketoacidosis

 

Mucormycosis, also known as zygomycosis, is a serious fungal infection caused by molds of the order Mucorales. This infection is strongly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) because the acidic environment and elevated glucose levels in DKA favor the growth and proliferation of Mucorales.

 

In diabetic ketoacidosis, there is also the high level of free iron due to the acidosis, which facilitates the growth of Mucorales fungi. The compromised immune system in diabetes also makes individuals more susceptible to infections, including mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregnancy: Pregnancy is generally not associated with an increased risk of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis: Pneumocystis jirovecii causes a different type of infection, pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is different from the fungi causing mucormycosis. It is primarily associated with exposure to bird or bat droppings and does not have a strong link to mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a significant risk factor for mucormycosis due to the favorable conditions it creates for the growth of Mucorales fungi, highlighting the need for vigilance in managing patients with DKA to prevent this serious fungal infection.

 

﻿Other causes include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Covid-19
  • ﻿Excessive iron overload
  • ﻿﻿Chronic dialysis

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.
